page.description: Here’s my blog entries in reverse chronological order:
Emanote allows you to use queries to dynamically generate static lists. For example, all ([[blog]],[])!
I’ve chosen to license this blog and all of its entries with the Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license going forward.
In ([[rust]],[]) you can easily take a reference of any value with the & operator. But something I’ve been having in the back of my head recently is why the following works:

I live in France, in the middle of the countryside. I enjoy it here, as its quieter than in a city and the air is, usually, clean. But one thing that it is missing is the density of infrastructure that a city can afford. Of course I knew that coming here, but it is still annoying going to the next town just to post a letter.
I’ve been using Anki for at least 7-8 years now and I found it an amazing way to learn things, however a few things imo are not always spelled out clearly and make it harder to use than it has to be.

I really enjoy ([[nixos]],[Str "NixOS"])NixOS, and have been using it for about two years now. However there’s one thing that has really started to annoy me lately: You cannot easily do partial updates due to how nixpkgs is built.
Stuff related to being a furry on the internet
The more I keep reading the word Fursuit the less it keeps making sense…
Hemera is a snow-leopard with an orange basecolor.
Heya! I’m Hemera the Computer Cat. I’m writing here to remember stuff I’ve learned as well as things I’ve found interesting.
Flakes are an upcoming feature of nix the package manager.
([[nixos]],[]) is notoriously underdocumented, and it frankly has no structure that lends itself to be nicely documented. (Maybe ([[flakes]],[]) will provide some relief? I doubt it though.
Rust in this blog is exclusively about the programming language.
([[rust]],[]) is a statically compiled language. As such it excels, and is geared towards, static program structures. This means that some restrictions apply:

programming/rust/dynamic_in_static.md.title: Being Dynamic in a Static Language

page.description: Some notes on this, in my opinion, very important topic. It’s not meant to be groundbreaking or even relevant for anyone else. It’s basically just a braindump of how I see this topic.
